ancestors.content: It is also a major deal because of the hurdles the push for #CleanIndoorAir is facing globally: in the form of stubborn misinformation and confusion about how viruses like #COVID spread, and resistance — including from within the scientific community — to the idea that improving the quality of the air we breathe can bring substantial health and economic benefits. #COVIDIsAirborne https://mastodon.social/@mackayim2022/112878601369815405

account.note:
Rural FP anesthetist formerly of Fort St John, BC, Canada. Trained in Aus and UK. Now doing rural locums in Canada.

Blessed to live, work and play on the traditional, ancestral and unceded territory of the Tk’emlúps te Secwe̓pemc people.

#Science and #Medicine Twitter was invaluable to me as the guy at the pointy end of "if you have questions ask your doctor".

But also appreciate links to #music, #art, #photography, health equity and many other things #fedi22

ancestors.content: “"Had we had clean air solutions when COVID first came along, had we been able to walk into a room with the same confidence that we turn on a tap to drink water, we probably wouldn't have had a pandemic, and we definitely would have been able to manage it much easier," said Professor Brendan Crabb, director and chief executive of the Burnet Institute.”

ancestors.content: “Cleaning the air is not just about trying to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses like COVID… Poor indoor air quality can cause a disturbing range of health problems including cancer, stroke, heart disease and chronic conditions like asthma, with an estimated 3.2 million people dying prematurely each year from illnesses caused by indoor air pollution in homes.”

ancestors.content: “Public health economist Richard Bruns last year estimated the cost-benefit ratio of investing in #ventilation and #filtration in American buildings was 1:10 — just from reducing the risks of COVID infection alone. Dr Bruns calculated it would cost US$4 billion to improve #IndoorAirQuality in all buildings for 16 weeks over winter each year, when respiratory virus transmission is high, delivering a benefit of about $40 billion.”

ancestors.content:
“improving indoor air quality needn't be an expensive exercise. Newer buildings in Australia are often equipped with modern ventilation systems that "take care of most of the risk", she said, and older buildings can generally be retrofitted with cost-effective solutions.

But a critical first step, she said, is installing monitoring devices. These little metres measure problematic particles and gases like fine particulate matter (#PM25) from smoke and vehicle exhaust, and carbon dioxide,”

"The biggest obstacle in most countries is where this [issue] sits in the regulatory system,”

descendants.content: @auscandoc @nutmeg how, with the lack of staffing everywhere, is this not top of priority list to sort, even if you give aren’t concerned about long term heath etc, the staff costs🤷🏽‍♀️I just don’t get it, every time there is a covid wave, short staffing all around, higher costs because you have to get locum/agency workers🤷🏽‍♀️🤦🏽‍♀️madness

account.note: love working and living in different countries, learning mandarin, European, mother of a teen, paediatric infectious diseases🩺,ventilate schools, constructive discussion, my own opinions only, ✊🏾 🌻🇺🇦💙#ChildrensRights #BlackLivesMatter  #NHS #antifascist #InfectiousDiseases #Science #Art #Epi #paediatrics #Equality #HumanRights #WorldMusic

descendants.content:
@Kaetchi @nutmeg Bias and cognitive fallacies. Several.

Almost no-one likes buying insurance… but then bemoans the cost when they didn’t.

Perfect example of this is travel insurance.

Routinely it is shown that spending $Y to prevent A saves $Z down the track. But nudging people past that “I don’t want to spend” is hard.

descendants.content: @auscandoc During the summer 2019-20 bushfires, Canberra’s air was so smoke-laden it was like a packet of cigarettes a day. But that lasted for weeks, months—fires to our west, north (Blue Mountains, etc), north-east, east, south-east, and just south of metro Canberra. It was vile, and escaping it was impossible.

account.note: #accordion

fields.name: Bio
fields.value: Australian, former: statistician; expedition bushwalker, snow camping ski-tourer; also XCD skier, cycle tourer. Prostate cancer survivor. Major interests in baroque, classical, and both folk music and jazz. Living on Ngambri-Ngunnawal lands.

media_attachments.description: Sun through a smoke haze Kamloops BC.

card.title: Tintincognito (@RSMacKinnon@mstdn.ca)
card.description:
Attached: 1 image

Jul 25 EWE:  Canada — I’m sick of people trying to gaslight everyone by telling them “we’ve always had fires in Alberta.” Of course, we’ve always had fires. But the last few years are off the charts. I grew up here. The average used to be 12 HOURS of smoke cover in a summer. Now it’s days and weeks.  https://x.com/gilmcgowan/status/1816493679047012382 #ClimateCrisis
